A Project to make Replacement parts for Beyblade Metal Fusion(TM). So far, I have made a standard Performance Tip called Beyblade Base.stl
If you noticed, the first and last picture/file are the same except one id upside down. I recommend printing the upside down one.
The last 4 files are .wings files in case you want to edit it.
I added Beyblade Bases 6 and 7, and hopefully, they will be more printable. Update: 8/21/2014
A fixed version of Face_Bolt's has been uploaded which fixes an issue where the threads' direction was reversed.

• Download Beyblade Base.
  • Make Your own Performance Tip with it.
  • Print it and upload it as a derivative of this.
    OR
  • Download Face Bolt.
  • Print it.
  • :)
  • Yay!
  • Upload a picture!
    Thanks to meirm for testing it.

comments.author: Guest

comments.text: I tried printing some of the tips but wasn't able to get them to lay flat. ReplicatorG has mostly 90 degree rotations, and when I use the arbitrary rotation to get it mostly flat and upside down, it still wouldn't lay all the way flat.  The one that is already in the right position for printing "base2 upsidedown" had too little support on the bridging portion. You might make that cross bar at least the width of the tip. Also make it a little thicker. Bridging like that tends to be pretty loosely attached the first couple of layers. The ring did turn out about the right size though. I think it could stand to be a bit deeper/thicker though too. Printed parts don't have the strength of molded parts, so they tend to need a bit more thickness along each dimension.

author: pdblas

description.text:
This is a collar I created to pass a USB cord through a tabletop without leaving a giant hole in the surface.  A 5/8" hole will just allow the flat USB connector to pass through, then the two halves of this collar can be pressed around the cord itself and the collar screwed into place.  
The holes are wide enough for #6 screws.  I used pan head screws on this one rather than a recessed hole, because the recessed screw holes take up more surface area and I wanted to keep the collar as small as possible.
Printed in PLA, 3 outer shells, 20% infill.

title: CTC / Flashforge: Schnellwechsel-Halter für Standard Glasplatte

description.text:
Ich habe nach einer Lösung gesucht, wie man eine Glasplatte schnell ein- und ausbauen kann. Haaspray sollte nicht mehr im Drucker aufgesprüht werden. Somit habe ich die folgende Vorrichtung mal am CAD zusammen gebastelt:
Vorrichtung zum schnellen Ein- und Ausbauen einer Standard Glasplatte mit 2mm Stärke. Glasplatte 240x180 aus rahmenlosen Bildhalter ( z.B.bei DM oder Rossmann erhältlich). Platte wird durch 2 Exzentrerhebel in ihrer Lage fixiert. Höhe der Hebel ist so ausgelegt, dass Active Duct V2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:537918 knapp darüber hinweg kommt. Achtung: Bei erstem Einsatz das Bett ganz nach unten Schrauben, um ein versehentliches Aufsetzen mit dem Extruder zu vermeiden ! Bauteile:
4x Senkschraube ISO 10642 M3x16
4x Sechskantmutter M3
2x selbstsichernde Sechskantmutter M3
2x Zylinderschraube M3x20

ABS
4 Shells
50% infill
Support

title: "hey!! you are out of filament" alarm 1.75mm

description.text:
koehler 1.75mm or 3mm filament alarm I made this so as the spool winds down to the end I could have a chance to get to my printer to reload without wasting filament on an unfinished part. It happens more than you think. All parts can be sourced from radio shack for less than 10 dollars (or your preferred source). 1 â€“ 1.75mm or 3mm filament alarm body printed in your favorite color 1 â€“ SPDT Switch with roller lever pn 275-017 1 â€“ Piezo buzzer pn 273-017 1 â€“ electrical connector (molex 4 pin or 2 pin 0.10â€ connector or 9v battery plug as you prefer) 2 â€“ #4 1/2â€ screws (home depot) 22 ga. Wire in your preferred colors. 4 to 10 ft depending on your power source Solder (or crimp) wires to the N.C and C connectors of the spdt switch. The middle tab or N.O. will not be used Solder the piezo buzzer close to the opposite end of the wiring for the switch. Attach your preferred electrical connector to the buzzer and 2nd wire from the switch. I use a 12v DC outlet from my ATX power supply but a 9v battery will work just as well. Polarity does matter here so take a moment to test. (the buzzer will work with reversed polarity but not loud and clear) Print 1 koehler 1.75mm filament alarm body and attach the sdpt switch using 2 screws thru the plate and into the switch mount holes. Adjust to open switch. Feed filament through the alarm then plug in to your preferred power source. When not using it, Insert a short piece of filament as a placeholder. The other way is loud and annoying. Youâ€™ll know what I mean when it goes off. Attach to 8mm rod above the extruder. The higher the better for time to get to your printer. The long slot allows the alarm body to swivel to avoid binding. I also cover the threaded rod with a straw split lengthwise to minimize friction. Great for direct attachment to Prusa Mendel style printers or an 8mm rod attached to a spool holder.
Rest at ease knowing it will tell you â€œ Hey buddy, Iâ€™m out of filamentâ€ throughout the house. Tell a friend.

comments.text: Nice design, thank you for sharing! I just wanted to share an alternative solution for people with closed source printers that cant be hacked to pause printing. My way uses a stand alone alarm system that can hook up to any printer in seconds. It also has bowden tube and oiler attachments! Check it out here: https://engineerdog.com/low-filament-alarm/
comments.author: MechEngineerMike

comments.text: The switch could be wired up to a GPIO port on a Raspberry Pi if you're running OctoPrint / OctoPi on one, to interface with the "Filament Sensor" plugin for that. This will provide automatic print-pausing in the event of a run-out.

comments.text: I've just got a 1-5Kg load cell for < £10 that I will work into a spool holder so that I can have Marlin weight the filament real time and get a good idea of how much I have left. A switch like this will be a good fail safe, but I'd like a good hint that I'll be running close to out before I start as some prints will be running over night.

title: Indispensable Dispenser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Drinks Dispenser inspired by my favourite animal: The Tapir.
http://www.factzoo.com/mammals/tapir-big-snout-beast.html
The photo shows the model with small "snouts" in the ends.
I have also included a model without theese, since they will break of if you drop the dispenser on a hard floor during an animated party (sorry).
Designed using the Discover Radial-Symmetry option in T-Splines for Rhinoceros. Base-geometry created in the Subdivisional-Surfacing-3D-software "Silo" from NeverCenter.com - Also available on Steam.

comments.text: The dangerous thing isn't PLA itself - its the contaminants in the print. Unless you're printing with very high quality PLA from a very reputable manufacturer, there is likely to be impurities in the filament that could contaminate your liquids. Even if you have pure PLA, many nozzles have traces of lead which make their way into the print and could cause damage.
comments.author: Simon_Vance

comments.text: There is almost certainly some amount of lead in the brass, but the amount that would end up in the the print, and the amount that would end up in the surface is so small as to be undetectable. The other things.. yeah.. not sure the stuff in the plastic is going to all be great.  Contact time won't be much so it doesn't seem likely to be a major concern, but worth considering.  The strength of the alcohol and potentially the acidity of the mixers may play an important roll.

title: Artificial Sunrise Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: As a project for our electrical engineering (for mechanical engineers) class, and since Ottawa mornings can be extremely dark, me and my group decided to build a lamp that could simulate the sunrise during the morning to help with waking up. My modular gear reducers, which i posted about a month ago, were designed for, and played a huge role in, this project. Once built, the lamp plugs into a wall timer, and as long as the control switch is open (optional part) the lamp begins turning on as soon as electricity is applied from the wall timer. These kinds of lamps exist for purchase, but usually go for around $200. We spent around $70 total, but you could definitely build it for much less. Video at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9fHnanEdq4w

I think the pictures I took of it, and the wiring diagram in the pictures will provide a good overview of how to assemble it. There's not much hidden.
The motor gear is glued to the spur gear mount to allow the mount to be easily bolted to the motor shaft. Make sure that they are very well centred, as eccentricity can cause wobbling and noise.
A few things were changed from the given circuit diagram. We used a dimmer instead of two different sized resistors (don't run this with a dimmer for a long time, especially with abs, theoretically the motor will heat up and be dangerous, though we were careful and never had any problems, I never leave it running unattended). Also, we just used a standard dimmer in series with the lightbulb to control that as well, instead of a potentiometer.
As mentioned, we spent around $70 total, and that was with completely new parts. We even bought a new fan to salvage the motor from (it was cheaper than buying a motor by itself, and was AC so it didn't require any conversion). If you have any spare wires, motors, parts, etc. laying around your cost will be greatly reduced.

comments.text: "I never leave it running unattended" lol
comments.author: hintss

comments.text: I know, kind of defeats the point doesn't it :-P. I'm trying to find resistors that are resistive enough and rated for that kind of power level to replace the dimmer, but no luck so far...
comments.author: hintss

comments.text: Seems like you guys have gone through some trouble to make this into a mechanical engineering assignment again! Using a TRIAC would be easier, but this is way cooler ;) I really like mechanical solutions. Figuring you guys are mech. eng. you do too!
comments.author: Erik

comments.text: I wish I had talked to you before we started the project :-P. When it was assigned at the start of the class, we had no background on these kinds of circuits at all (and to be honest we still dont ;)) so this was our solution. I was surprised, we got very good mark on it, I guess our prof likes mechanical solutions too :).
comments.author: Erik

comments.text: That's cool. :) I think it is always good practice to solve a solution in a familiar domain, while also talking to people who are familiar with other domains. The most interesting solutions arise where ideas 'clash'.

title: FrankenForge! - 52mm Spool Holder for FlashForge Creator Pro & Clones
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Welcome to FrankenForge! I'm consolidating my designs for the FlashForge Creator Pro / PowerSpec 3D Pro Printer and all associated clones under the FrankenForge! name. This is my latest design: 608 Bering Spool mount replacement intended for the FFCP/PS3DP Printers with 30mm tube mounts for filament spools. This is designed for use with spools that have a 52mm inner diameter and a width of 62 - 70mm (Makerbot, Inland and Microcenter house brand filaments all fit fine). This is intended to replace the stock spool tubes completely, and will require drilling 4 holes in the back of your printer's housing. Unlike other designs, this relies on the bolt head and the coupling nut pressure on the bearings to hold the whole thing together, as opposed to the bearing mounts needing to be exactly the right size to be pressure fit into the 52mm hole. That allows for some variance in the spool size as well as printing variation. Parts List Printed
Base Plate x1
Half Tube x2
Wingnut Top x1 Other
M8 100mm Bolt x1
M8 24mm Coupling Nut x1
M3 12mm Socket Head Bolt x4
M3 Locking Nuts x4
M3 Washers x4
M3 Lock Washers x4
608 Bering (Standard Skateboard Bering) x2
Glue - I would suggest Loctite Go2Glue

Print Settings Note - These are designed to be printed at 3mm extrusion, 100% infil with support turned on.  I printed them with PLA, but ABS should work just fine as well.  
1: Print the base plate.  Drive the coupling nut into the base plate so that it's even with the round side and sticking out a few millimeters from the square side.  
2: Remove the existing plastic mounting tube and plastic nuts from the printer.  
3: Put the base plate into the 30mm hole from the rear ourside of the printer, and temporarily secure with blue painting tape.  
4: After squaring the base plate up, drill matching holes into the back plate of the printer using the 4 corner holes as a guide.  
5: Using the 4 12mm M3 screws, washers, lock-washers and locking nuts to secure the back plate to the rear of the printer.  
6: Glue the Wing Nut Top to the head of the M8 100mm bolt.  Allow to dry completely.  
7: Mount the 2 Half Pipe parts, 2 608 Bearings and the M8x100 bolt to your spool of filiment.  
8: Mount the spool to the back plate by tightening down the bolt into the coupling nut until it's finger tight to the berrings.

remixed_from.title: Ignignokt and err from agua teen hunger force

description.text: Tried to keep the shape about right, but I had to enlarge Err a bit to make the magnet fit. They should puzzle-piece together to form the quad-laser (sans quad-laser).

1/8" x 1/4" inch disc magnets magnets The two color, non-dual extruder or pause way using cura:
  • Print the bottom/base.
  • For the "whole".stl - setup your slicer to remove the bottom 3.5 mm (3.6mm if you do 0.2mm layer height) for ignignokt and 3.0mm for Err
  • Set your start height the same distance as the removal height for each character
    • Also, I set my fill to 100% for the top layer because my filament is translucent.

The Koehler audible bed leveling tool. Tired of painful exacting bed leveling? Try this for a quick painless method. All parts are available from your local radio shack for less than 15 dollars. Use with thing 97151 to get your bed just right. You will need:

  • Piezo buzzer 3-20v pn 273-059

  • Gator clip (large enough to attach to your hotend)

  • PCB (copper clad board) cut into four pieces

  • 22 ga wire (8 -12 ft)

  • 4.7k ohm resistor

  • power source (9v battery or molex 4 pin for atx power supply connection. I prefer a 9v battery as some ATX power supplies will trip the breaker shutting down your power supply)

  • power supply connector depending on your preference of power supply. I personally use small gator clips to allow multiple options for power sources.

  • 4 bulldog clips (if you use a glass bed you already have the ones you need.)
    • Instructions

  • Cut PCB (copper clad board) into four 1â€x1â€ squares.

  • Solder a length of wire (12â€) to the top of each PCB square.

  • Combine all four wires together and attach to a fifth length of wire (2 â€“ 5 ft).

  • Solder piezo buzzer to opposite end of fifth wire.

  • Solder second wire from piezo buzzer to power supply connector.

  • Cut sixth wire to approximate length of first wire assembly.

  • Attach gator clip to sixth wire.

  • Solder 4.7k ohm resistor to opposite end of sixth wire.

  • Solder opposite end of resistor to second power supply connector. Polarity matters here so test the connection by switching + and â€“ for loudest buzzer sound first. Youâ€™ll know when you have it right.

  • Attach power supply connector to your chosen power supply

  • Test by touching gator clip to each PCB square.

  • Attach gator clip to metal section of hotend.

  • Using bulldog clips, Mount the four PCB squares to the corners of your heat bed. Make sure the PCBs sit flush to the heat bed.

  • Very important!! Clean the bottom of your hotend tip with a cloth and acetone to remove all filament. Only the lowest part of the tip matters. Do not file or sand the tip of your hotend unless you want to alter itâ€™s performance.

  • Move your hotend and heatbed to center tip above first PCB square. Adjust your spring retaining nut until the buzzer sounds. Go corner to corner and adjust your leveling springs until your bed is right where you want it. It may take a few times around to get it just right. I find that using this technique gives me an accuracy of 0.004mm. As good as it gets for me in less than 5 min. I recommend doing this with your heatbed at temp. You would be surprised at the difference. Also remember to orient your glass the same way each time. Its all about the details. Enjoy the rest of your day printing rather than fighting your heatbed using mechanic methods.

comments.text: thats a good article.  guess I'm a year behind so I better get at it.  I made a similiar tool for my cnc mill using mach3 .  It will automatically home x/y then z till the cutting bit makes contact with the pcb. it will subtract the thickness of the the pcb and set the z height making tool changes easier than without.  I have no doubt a program could be written to run prior to printing to repeat what mach3 does times 4 and calculate the exactly position of the corners. Just need a little collaboration as my programming skills lack in this area.   Anyone want to assist?

Turn the crank handle and the marbles are pumped up the vertical shaft to return down the spiral. Based on the mechanism seen here: http://www.sentex.net/~mwandel/marbles/pump.html. This marble pump could be combined with many of the other marble runs found on thingiverse.

I made the front, back and top panels in acrylic so that one can see the internal cylinder and piston mechanism. I've provided both stl and dxf versions of the panels for either printing or laser cutting. I actually cut and drilled mine by hand As well as the printed plastic and cut acrylic you'll need:
8 small panel screws. (4g x 10 mm)
2 metal rods 3 mm diameter, 110 mm long.
12 glass marbles ~15 mm diameter
~1.5 m of 3 mm filament for the rails and supports. The spiral rails, vertical supports and right angled bends were made by bending up 3 mm HIPLA (http://www.diamondage.geekofarm.com/?page_id=150). If using ordinary PLA it will probably be necessary to gently heat the filament to get nice curves and avoid breaking it. Print:
2 side_panel
1 piston
1 cylinder_block
1 set of crank_pieces
2 clip_90deg
4 clip_4_rail
8 clip_2_rail Print or Cut
2 front_back_panel
1 top_panel Have a look at the marble_pump.blend file, the photo and the render to work out assembly. Depending on the printing quality you may need to sand the piston and cylinder to get a good fit. The crank could be connected up to a motor for amusement.

This is  the knob that controls the seat position adjusting latch for the center seats of a Piper Aztec-F airplane.  May fit other models, I don't know.  This is Piper part no. 571-165.  
The design is not exact as I did not reproduce the beveled edges.  That seemed to be the point of diminishing returns.  The difference isn't all that noticeable and has no effect on functionality.  Feel free to add that.  
This probably will never be a top-ten Thing, but these knobs are absolutely impossible to find anymore.  This part was discontinued by Piper many years ago.
To duplicate the original, you'll need a metal sleeve drilled for a set screw.  Will probably also work as a simple press-on without the sleeve.  Adjust the variable shaftRadius to your preference.

This is hydroponics project re-uses beer cans to serve as hydroponics pots. There are 3 parts to this project. The Top, the Spout, and the Post. Build Video:
https://youtu.be/TynlrslVDTo

Parts:
1) 10in Bowl
2) a water pump: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00JWJIC0K/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
3) Tubing that fits your pump
4) 6 empty beer cans
5) Some kind of controller:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00P0TZ5CY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Step 1: Print the Beer_Hydro_Spout
Step 2: Print the Beer_Hydro_Post
Step 3: Print the Beer_Hydro_Top_Test
Step 4: Place the Beer Hydro Top Test across the 10in pot. The edges are beveled so it will sit partially on top as well as partially into the pot. This will allow it to sit on top, fairly stable. You also want to make sure the post fits. Due to some types of filament used, this post hole may need to be adjusted. So you want to make sure this is right before printing the next piece.
--There is a Beer_Hydro_Top_Test scad file. At the beginning are the adjusters. If your top does not fit correctly on the top of your pot or the post does does not fit correctly , adjust the top parameters until you have a print that fits. If the post does not fit into the slot, adjust the post_slotX and post_slotY parameters.
--Getting the post to fit into the top is probably the most difficult part of the project. I also included a Beer_Hydro_Top_Slot_Test file which allows you to print a small test piece to work with the post size. Step 5: Print the Beer_Hydro_Top using your adjusted settings from Step 4.
Step 6: Push the Beer_Hydro_Post into the Top. It should fit tightly but you don't want to break it.
Step 7: push your tubing up the post and attach it to the Spout.
Step 8: attach your pump to the tubing and place everything on top of the 10 pot/bowl.
Step 9: Cut the tops off of the beer cans. I used a plain old can opener.
Step 12: Make drain holes in the bottom if each can
Step 13: Fill the pots with your growing medium, I use rock wool.
Step 14: add the plants and place a can into a slot
Step 15, Move the spout around so that its is very close to the plant and the plant can grow around it.
Step 16: You will need to control the timing of the water. I used a simple timer and printed a box for it. You can use a raspberry pi, or Arduino also. Ill leave this part up to you to figure out how to do it, it should be straight forward.

description.text:
This is a cut-away sectional of the enzyme nitrogenase. Nitrogenase is the method than diazotrophs (nitrogen fixing organisms) utilize to convert the nitrogen gas found in the atmosphere (~78% of the atmosphere is nitrogen) into ammonia that can be used to make fundamental building blocks such as proteins and DNA. It is not the entire protein (I am working on that as well), but is the section that houses the two unique metal clusters that are found in this component.  
I included the FeMo-cofactor with homocitrate and P-cluster, along with many of the amino acids that surround these two cofactors. This is a nice example of how nature has brought together very intricate clusters and arranged them to make a very nice catalyst. I finished my model and painted the various cofacters (sulfur yellow and iron green), along with some of the secondary structure. Really happy with how this one turned out. I painted the braces with a steel paint to indicate that they are not really part of the structure.  
Structure is based on the 1MIN protein data bank crystal structure. Model was manipulated in VMD, transferred to Tinkercad, where it was cleaned and the supports added.

I printed this on a Makerbot Replicator 2. I did include a raft and supports. I also increased the size of mine to 150% the size of the original tinkercad version, so that it would be a little bit larger and more robust. I suggest you do the same if you attempt to print this. Warning, this was a 2 day (40 some hour) print at medium quality. I included quite a few braces, but with the new scaffolding (through the Makerbot software), it was only about an hour to remove this. I also used a modeling knife to clean everything up, and spent quite a bit of time painting mine, but I am very happy with it. I included some pictures. I'm doing several additional models similar to this of other important enzymes, and have a much larger project planned for this summer.

This is a mount and a duct for Peter Stoneham's dual extruder. It is my first design and a little wobbly but it is functional. You need a centrifugal fan for it. Link to the fan is below. Rotate the support arm 90 degrees to lay it down for better printing. The fan duct needs supports over the inlet mouth, i just put 2 to help with bridging and over the 2 arms that hang over. I used 2x M4 30 mm bolts and washers to mount the fan to the arm/duct. The arm is mounted to one of the linear bearing bolts. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00H8VV0XK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 update
I noticed the duct tends to sag during a warm print, added a second support to keep it level and above nozzle level

title: Longboard Wheelpulleys, 44 and 48 teeth HTD5 versions
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: These are remixed wheel pulleys for Bigfoot/APEX/Blank Pro wheels. This is ment to be used with 15mm wide HTD5 belts. Also the nuttraps are remixed to match M5 (metric) nuts. I am using the 44 teeth version currently. (still running strong, no issues, ~500km now) More info; https://nurdspace.nl/LongboardMod

Print thinwalled (about 1 nozzlewidth wide) and at 100% fill. Also, the thickest layers you can print. (probably ~80% of your nozzlewidth)
I used PLA, but suspect Nylon6 might also give good results.  
Fill the nuttraps with M5 nuts for each bolt you want to put in. (I am just using 2 in mine)  
This is ment for 15mm wide HTD5 belts, and for the 'thin' cored wheels of Bigfoot/APEX/Blank Pro.  
See brentyi's thingie for the retainer.

description.text:
• Revision: Made spool mount taller to avoid spool hitting printer motor at 10 inch print height

The spool width of this is 70mm, fits spools from 30mm to maybe 36mm in diameter. This was made specifically for the Hatchbox and JustPLA 1.75mm spools. It may work for other spools as well. All parameters are adjustable, the OpenSCAD file is included.

author: Saf

description.text:
Improved version of variable pitch propeller set: Some improvements to the rotor holder and the thing that changes the pitch (pitcher i call it) Testing them now (being printed ... really some mushrooms grow faster that 3D printed parts) This design allows you to have the main shaft fixed from the top and the bottom (better use metal joints as ABS will melt on high RPM (even on 1000) ... will post photos after full assembly v2.5:
  • Improved rotor holder (print separated with no supports at all)
  • improved 'pitcher'
    ' longer shaft for support from top

• Try printing the rotor holder with no supports, slow speed 204c temp
  • Print everything else with full support
    • 1- put 2 rotor holders on the shaft, opposite from eachother, have a 3mm screw with 4mm head into them to hold onto the shaft (make sure not too tight becuase the rotor holders should be able to move) 2- slide the pitcher from under the shaft, with the upper hands into the rottor-holders. 3- attach the rotors 4- the bottom of the shaft should be drilled/heated to be fixed on a motor or drive-shaft 5- the top of the shaft should be a fixed screw that moves with the shaft, slided into a metallic housing in some upper arm, this should be metallic otherwise the shaft will melt on high rpm 6- the 'pitcher' has a hollow ring, should add some metallic ring there as well (which will be like a rail for the servo shaft to move the pitcher up and down) ... Video make sure all parts that have friction between them (the pitcher-ring:servo and main-shaft:top-arm are metallic otherwise the will meltdown mid-flight and might lead to serious injury and/or damage ... really bad damage for such big rotors
This is a model of a bowling pin made to scale.

title: Apple Watch Charging Wall Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a wall mount for the Apple watch that uses an Apple 'ice cube' charger.  
The watch band can either drape over the edges, or it can be tightened around the back of the cylinder if you have a large band.  
I successfully printed it using standard settings with 3 shells and 20% infill, and it turned out well.  
Good luck and happy printing!

comments.text:
I printed one of these. While pretty awesome. It wastes a lot of filament that doesn't need to be used.
I also had to duck take the back to the charger, everytime I unplugged it from the wall, the usb cord would come out of the charger, and charger stay in the wall. a real PITA to get it out of there. basically have to unwrap the cord again. The overhangs are a B to print. One suggestion for design would be a cover to cover up the cord part. Could be pretty easy to make another piece that overlaps. Been using my for a year. Works well. Wish it was a little smaller so my medium sport band would latch around it.

Inspired by CCphoto's "Another spool" ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8208 ), this spool is parametric, minimalistic, and designed to make changing filaments easy. To add a roll, hook the arm pieces around it, slide the rods into the slots in the arms, and tighten the nuts to clamp it. At the default size, it can hold a 5 lb roll as pictured, though it's probably better to use it with half the roll. On a Mendel, you could print one large enough for a 20 lb roll! It includes variables for the arm size and number of the arms (designed to work with 3 or 4, but 5 and 6 should also work) as well as the diameter of the bearings and of the rods. I have included STLs for a version for m8 rod with 608 bearings and for the one I made, with m6 rod and some R188 bearings that I had lying around, both with 3 arms that will fit on a Cupcake's platform.

Print 1 hub and the appropriate number of arms. Attach with threaded rods 9-12" long. I'm using it with my minimalistic spool mount ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8472 ), but most mounting systems designed for other spools should work.

author: yakwool

description.text: An extended "universal" version of the "easy adjustable" J-head mount with various improvements, including a printable Bowden clamp, option for fusion with effector, and support for one, two, or three hot-ends.

NOTE: not yet fully tested. I have printed and test-fitted, but I'm still assembling my Kossel. In particular I don't know if the Bowden clamps will be strong enough. Note also that this is appropriate for the "legacy" Kossel and will not work with the current version in the git repo, which now uses a smaller effector. Files for the legacy Kossel are at https://github.com/jcrocholl/kossel/tree/legacy. I do include (a slightly modified version of) the effector from there in my download (for visualization purposes, but also to print fused with the top plate as an option... saves three bolts and their weight). This is a universal J-head mounting system for a Bowden cable effector for the legacy Kossel. You can mount one, two, or three hot ends. The mounting plate is universal and will work with all three versions of the insert. You can also adjust the leveling by adjusting the mounting screws. In addition, there are printable Bowden clamps. For these, pick either the single or double-high version, depending on how paranoid you are, and mount them using a countersunk bolt pushed up from underneath the plate and one or two cable ties. WARNING: Many electronics, i.e. the RAMP1.4, only support dual extruders at most. You will have to be creative to get a third extruder working. Improvements over the original:
  • Mounting holes now line up with holes on effector.
  • Recessed nut captures on bottom now have cathederal ceilings to print better
  • More space around insert to allow it to be adjusted better
  • Larger nut captures and holes that work with M3 bolts and nuts
  • Large enough hole for either a 4mm PFTE Bowden tube or a 8mm push-mount
  • Universal hole system. Note that sometimes you use a hole for a mounting pin for the insert, sometime you use it for a Bowden mount. Feel free to use any extra holes for cable management.
  • Option for fused effector and mounting plate.
    • Update: Pictures, option for fused plate/effector. Update 2: License for effector is GPL (see git repo referenced above), license for original mount was Creative Commons - Share Alike. I'm not sure what the resulting license should be, but for now I'm making the whole thing Creative Commons - GPL, which I believe is more restrictive. However, really everything but effector.scad, configuration.scad, and fused_plate.stl should be Creative Commons - Share Alike. Someone please correct me in the comments. I suppose I should split out the files with the GPL license into a separate thing...

comments.text:
Just what I am looking for, I am not an expert at CAD, but I was thinking that the only thing missing was an integrated level probe option now that marlin supports it on a delta. Preferably through the center of the effector on dual and triple configurations and off center in the single configuration. And possibly a home retract in the sketch. Do you think that would be difficult? Or is it already in your inventory for development? I was going to try using the Allen wrench type of auto level build but Hall effect and optical are also an option obviously.
(I only have the hardware for the Allen wrench style atm and was thinking that a ball ended style would yield more precise result. )
Even though the auto assemblies are quite light I think that center of mass and the center of the effector should be as close as possible.
Thoughts on the above? Also what material do you think would be be best, #of shells, infill etc do you plan on using.
I fear even attempting a remix since so much careful work has been done on this. What a great upgrade to the standard delta effector!
Really great work.

author: jcc2617

description.text:
Needed some luggage tags, designed them using http://thinkandhave.de/personalizer/ and then needed a durable clip to fix them at the cases. This thing consists of an open ring that can be locked with a screw (m3 x 12mm). The model can be changed to other diameters for the ring (change variable ring).
I use two rings, 20mm for the luggagetag and 40mm for the suitcase handle.

Open the model in OpenSCAD, you may change the diameter of the ring. Render and save as STL, then print.
If you like two rings (20mm and 40mm diameter) in one print, then directly print 2clips.stl. For each ring a screw (preferred m3, 12mm, longer will work too) is needed.

author: Luke203

description.text:
Are you tired of buying expensive toys for your bathtub, pool, or collection of things that float. We have you covered here at Makersome. With this easy print item you will be getting nautical in no time. Never worry about losing the Surfboard to the deep 6, cause another copy is just a push of the button away. Instructions:

  • Download the STL file for the Surfboard

  • Pop it into your slicer of choice

  • We recommend using PLA with extruder setting of 200°C with 20% infill so it floats

  • If you do not have a Glass Bed Upgrade Kit then we recommend not to use a heated bed, but if you do have the Glass Bed Upgrade Kit then we recommend using a bed temp of 70°C

  • There is no need to use rafting or supports while printing this project

  • Load your project onto an SD card or connect your computer to your printer (just use your preferred method here)
    • Congratulations, you're ready to print! Check out our 3D Printing Projects page at:
    http://makersome.com/3d-printing-projects/ Check out our Youtube channel at:
    https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCv00IAervOUnsipGhwTC9rA
    If you like what you see Please Comment and Subscribe.

title: XLRobots.com's X1 Opensource Female Robot Companion

description.text:
XLRobots is proud to introduce the X1:Female Robot Companion. A life size 100% 3d printable robot. This is a robot project that will be free to the public from the creative minds at XLRobots.com. The robot design is complete and the slicing part has begun. Check daily for the finished parts to be added for download. First up will be her head and neck parts followed by the torso,rear and arms. The robot is designed to be controlled by the Powerful Ez-Robot V4 controller. The combination of the design skills of XLRobots.com and the Power of Ez-Robot controller and software will bring the X1 to life!
https://youtu.be/ePDBWk0aGYA

description.text: Kendama Version II I was concerned with my first design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:806955), since the weakest bond is between layers, I figured the base-cup/handle/spike would be too weak and break. I was surprised it worked as well as it did; however after many breaks and lots of super-glue, I decided it was time for a re-design. With this version, the Handle/Spike print horizontally (in halves), taking advantage of the strength that provides, and eliminated the need for the "bulge" in my previous design's BigCup/LittleCup part required for strength. All the parts twist-fit together (no glue required). This also allows for interesting color variations...

I printed all the parts with 70% infill, for the density/weight; particularly the ball.  At that density, with ABS, it is very close to the weight of a wooden ball.  
Print two handle halves, and one each of the other parts.  
The "tabs" on the handle halves will probably need a little cleanup with a knife to remove the "flanging" that occurs with the first layer (being slightly squished), in order to fit into the "keyhole" slots of the other parts.  They should be a snug fit (hence no glue necessary).  
Attaching the cups with a 90-degree twist, secures the cups, and binds the two handle halves together.

description.text:
This is a replacement clamp for the Y-axis drive belt.  It allows the belt tension to be fine tuned without removing the bed.
One end of the belt is clamped to the Y chassis "squashed frog" with the standard clamp.  After threading the belt around the motor and pulleys, the other end passes under the gap in the new clamp, loops back over the top of the clamp and is held down with the cap.  The whole thing is held the carriage with 2 3mm cap screws and nylocks just like the old bracket.  The ram is placed into the loop where the belt doubles back.   A 4mm cap screw goes through the back of the clamp and pushes the ram forward.  By turning the cap screw, you can change the tension on the belt.
This design might work just fine without the ram and be a little easier to assemble.  I haven't tried it.

Print out the cap, ram, and clamp.
Clean them up as usual and tap the hole in the clamp for the 4mm cap screw.
Thread the cap screw in.
Loosely assemble everything on the mendel.
Pull the reasonable tight and tighten the 3mm scres holding everthing to the carriage.
Adjust the tension with the 4mm cap screw.

This is my Retropie Portable implementation.  I put it together as a design challenge, a chance to learn more about using the Raspberry Pi, and to have a fun hand-held battery-powered gaming console.  
My main design goal was to have good ergonomics.  This design fits nicely with my large hands, with an analog joystick that I find more comfortable than a D-pad.  I really didn't like the feel of the little tactile membrane buttons everyone else is using, so I opted for these nice 16mm illuminated mechanical pushbuttons instead.  They have a really smooth action, feel much nicer for prolonged play sessions, and have the additional bonus of being panel mount instead of PCB mount which makes fitting them in the case simpler.  
There are only 2 pieces to print with this design.  Admittedly, they are large pieces, about 240mm wide.  Mechanical assembly is simple, nearly all the electrical parts attach to the case with small self-tapping screws, most of them to the front half with just the battery and charger board attaching to the rear.  
It has an internal battery charger, and can be played while charging - although you will discharge faster than you charge, so you still need to shut down to recharge fully.  The second USB port on the PI is accessible, so you can plug in a USB drive to transfer roms, or an external keyboard for configuration or emulating systems needing a keyboard.  
I'm using a Teensy 2.0 for the joystick function.  There is a mode switch button which can be used to switch the teensy into a keyboard emulator mode that maps the joystick to arrow keys and the various buttons to certain keypresses, so you can navigate the file transfer utility and some of the other configuration menus without needing a keyboard.  
No internal speakers - the amp was drawing too much current and the speakers were hard to fit, so I decided to make it headphone-only.  
I wouldn't recommend that anyone build this as is and am uploading it for reference purposes.  There are a handful of things that I'm not happy with that would be fixed on a redesign.  For one thing, I'm using an original model Raspberry Pi B for this, while a new design should be based around a Pi 2.  
These pictures were taken before I had the soft power control circuit working.  Since then I have replaced the toggle switch with a button and included a circuit to turn power on by button-press and off when the Pi shuts down.  A schematic is included.  
In order to fit everything in the space behind the display, I had to forgo connector and solder wires directly to the back of the Raspberry Pi.  Between that and all the wires to the illuminated pushbuttons, this is not a design to attempt unless you're very comfortable with a soldering iron.  
The case is nearly 240mm wide, so you'll need a large bed printer to print it.  It barely fit on my 250mm circular bed.  Both front and rear case halves will need to be printed with support.

Parts I used: 1 printed front case half
1 printed rear case half RaspBerry Pi Model B: https://www.adafruit.com/products/998
Teensy 2.0: http://www.adafruit.com/products/199
Battery: https://www.adafruit.com/products/328
Powerboost 500 + charger: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1944
2-axis analog joystick: http://www.adafruit.com/products/245 Illuminated pushbuttons: 2x white: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1479
1x red: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1439
1x green: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1440
1x yellow: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1441
3x blue: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1477 I also used two non-illuminated buttons from this pack of 15: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1009 8gb SD card from amazon or anywhere else really
4.3" TFT Display: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005CFLMNC The toggle switch show in some of the pictures is not included in the final design, being replaced by a button along with the new power control circuit attached to the Powerboost 500. Note that you will have to desolder one part on the Powerboost board to use the included power control circuit. Five 220 ohm 1/8W resistors for the blue and white illuminated pushbuttons, and three 330 ohm 1/8W resistors for the red, yellow, and green illuminated pushbuttons. The display was modified by removing the stand, rear case, and small board with pushbuttons. I also desoldered the cable off the main board and replaced it with wires soldered directly to the back of the Raspberry Pi for power and composite video. The display I used seems to be able to run directly off 5V without modification and I have it taking power directly from a header on the Pi. For the connection between the Teensy and the Pi, I cut an old USB cable in half and soldered wires directly to the USB connector pins on the underside of the Pi. Note that this has to be done to the 4 pins closer to the edge of the board to get the lower USB port, leaving the upper one free for an external USB device. The Teensy is wired to the joystick, 8 illuminated pushbuttons, and 1 non-illuminated pushbutton. Connections are as follows: Analog 0: x input from joystick
Analog 1: y input from joystick
Digital 0: A button
Digital 1: X button
Digital 2: Y button
Digital 3: B button
Digital 4: R button
Digital 5: L button
Digital 6: Start button
Digital 7: Select button
Digital 8: mode select button The display screen, the Raspberry Pi, and the Powerboost are held in place with small self-tapping screws. I use the ones that come with the micro servos my robots keep going through since I have a lot of them spare. The front and back of the case are held together with four M3 socket head screws and hex nuts.

title: Rigidbot Dual V6 Mk8 Alloy Mount Part-Fan Nozzle

description.text:
I looked at various configurations but settled on this centrally mounted 40mm centrifugal fan concept. The nozzle design clips firmly into the particular fan I chose and serves as a part-fan for both extruders, furthermore, it can be lifted out of the way as required. I spent some time with smoke studies to get the right nozzle shape and it has already proven its worth printing thin-walled parts including its own nozzle (0.8mm wall). I have never used a part fan before but I can see now that it is an essential tool in the FDM tool kit! Easy to print with both exhaust nozzles on the print bed. I optomised the design for 0.4mm extruder nozzles with no infill, however, I recommend using a part fan to print this...
I have uploaded the original mounting bracket and arms which is a work in progress. I have also added an optional bracket to the end of the nozzel so that it can sit on the rail. I added the brim for adhesion in the solid model - obviously you need to cut this off once printed.
The assembly requires five M3 screws; A 20mm one that holds the fan, two 8mm long screws to secure the arms onto the top mounting bracket and two 6mm ones to secure the assembly onto the alloy mount. Here is where I got the fan from; http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Plastic-10PCS-GDT-DC-24V-2P-Brushless-Cooling-Blower-Fan-40mm-40x20mm-4cm/32270564254.html

comments.text: Would it be possible to see the original part file for the nozzle? I ordered the part fan from Rigidbot directly thinking it was the same but it is not. I would like to try to modify the opening to fit that fan better.

author: bs3

title: Dji phantom quadcopter style shell / frame

description.text:
The design is finished. I don't think I will be changing anything else. I have printed all the parts and they now seem to fit nicely. If any of have any issues let me know. Dji phantom style quadcopter Shell / frame. Now you can print the lighter arms and bottom shell and cut around 100 grams.
Changes made to make it lighter and easier to put together.
This quad is printable on a standard 200 mm by 200 mm print bed. It is a work in progress. The battery cover is forthcoming.
I would love some input form all of you on any design modifications or ideas.
There are thin round supports under the round hole in the top shell that need to be snapped out after printing. The motor mounts are based on common 19 mm by 16 mm motor mounts.
The battery bay has 6 mounting holes for rails or gimbal. The bottom is thick enough to drill and mount landing gear, I am using retractable gear when they come in.
it looks like the weight of the frame is around 260 grams to 300 grams depending on your print settings you use.
I designed a large battery bay for large mah batteries.
The battery bay is 32mm by 47mm by 145mm. It will take 5200 mah Walkera x350 pro style batteries with the extended battery bay.
Link.
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__62884__MultiStar_High_Capacity_3S_5200mAh_Multi_Rotor_Lipo_Pack.html

Use support for the top shell when printing. There is built in support under the round part on the top shell that need to be snapped out once you finish printing. So There is no need for support material for the battery bay, bottom shell or cap.
You do however need support for the top shell, I did print one with out support but I would not advise that unless your printer is tuned like a Steinway. The arms can be screwed together or supper glued if you are using pla, witch I recommend, or both. Then drill the bottom using the hole in the arm as a guide and glue the arm into the bottom with super glue

Designed for a Camfive laser engraver, but seems usable for any basic hinge need.  
The black one in the back is the original, but that's the last picture I'll ever have of one since they're all gone now.

Printed it solid at .3 layer height. A bit of warping on the underside of the upwards curve, but did not effect the final product's functionality at all.  
The model turns around and fits into itself. No need to mirror.  
Uses a .25 bar for the hinge pin and fits very snug but usable on a larger door without anything to hold it in place when mounted horizontally. Haven't done any vertical testing.  
The original was injection molded was designed to be mostly hollow. I'm assuming to save a bit of plastic, but at the loss of any long term rigidity. So after 2 of them broke within a year, I designed my own . Now I have replaced them all, and threw away the old unbroken ones.  
Edit: after a couple weeks of frequent  use the hinge separated at the first layer of the loop under the pressure of the strut. Printing it vertically with supports seems to make it a lot stronger, and I'm hoping not to have this issue. Normal situations shouldn't be a problem, but this thing weighs as much as a car hood and lifted itself off the hinges when they popped, so it was way more pressure than anticipated.

title: Money Tree... Money does grow on trees!

description.text:
A 'just for fun' print as a talking point this is a small and easy print that lets you make your own 'Money Tree'. No support required and it doesn't use much filament.... once printed just add some notes and you have evidence that money 'does grow on trees... if they are 3D printed! The Money Tree should work with almost any denomination of bank notes. Just fold them in half lengthwise, push them into the top of the designed in slots (with the centre piece up through the fold in the note to hook it in place) then slide the note to the bottom of the slot. There is a top slot that works in the same way but the angle has been reduced so the top not stands near upright but will still stay in place.
There are seven slots in total so seven notes are required. It goes without saying I wouldn't recommend using notes of high value for a display piece like this.... Note: Before inserting your bank notes check each slot is clear by slipping a piece of paper in/out just in case there has been some filament stringing during printing. ...and, if you like this, check out my other fun, unique, novel and practical designs!

This is a straight forward print on a Replicator 2 or 5th Generation Replicator so should print well on most machines.   
Use 0.20mm/Std. resolution with Raft, 4 shells and at least 30% infill. This is done to make sure it is solid in any thin areas... it's a small print so doesn't use much filament even with these settings.

title: 3 mm Lasercut Deckbox with Living Hinge (SVG/AI)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Zypher256k made this awesome deckbox, but only published it as a CoralDraw file! Not everyone has CoralDraw, and it's a proprietary format. In addition, they used 5 mm wood, which is somewhat uncommon. So, I modified it! The name says it all, really. This should hold a standard sized, unsleeved MTG deck. I will soon modify it to hold a double sleeved deck.
Cut the red lines on 3 mm plywood. Glue the pieces together, then epoxy a magnet and washer to it to keep it closed. If you want to stain the box like I did, do so after gluing but before epoxying.

Warning: This is a challenging item to print, and requires tight tolerances.  
This is a GPS stalk designed around the 3DR GPS, and Sky Hero Spy (or other copters that use a 30mm boom).  It folds for travel, keeps all of the wiring internal, and has a mounting on the bottom for a standard telemetry or UHF antenna.

You'll need a 14mm carbon tube, 4 self tapping M2x8mm screws (6mm will also work), 2 M3x12mm bolts with matching nuts, some epoxy or CA to adhere the 'mast inner' part to your carbon fibre tube, a GPS extension cable, and an SMA antenna extension lead to mount telemetry or UHF antenna.

author: Tctat

title: Marker float - Boya señalizadora
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It´s the perfect tool to mark the priming point. It´s recommended to print in a highly visible color PLA (biodegradable). To increase the buoyancy reduce piece infill. After having printed the piece, you must tie and roll 30m rope around the marker. Finally, you have to attach a lead at the end of the rope (60-100g).  
Es la herramienta perfecta para marcar el punto de cebado. Se recomienda imprimirlo en PLA (biodegradable) y en un color muy visible. Para aumentar la flotabilidad reducir el relleno al máximo. Tras haber imprimido la pieza, se deberá atar y enrollar unos 30m de cuerda alrededor del marcador. Finalmente, se deberá atar un plomo en el extremo de la cuerda (60-100g).

author: rolfwalz

title: A-Type bowden X carriage for 3dp02 Prusa Mendel

description.text:
UPDATE!!! I re-uploaded sides with minor changes but very usefull. Revised radius in some holes and increased, just a bit, the gap por belt. Now, final testing on printer.
    • This is my own design for the bowden x-carriage. Main target was to reduce as much as possible tilt influence on printing, so, the tip is almost on the same plane than bars.
    Another plus point is that it is modular and can be adapted for as many hot-ends as you want (always in a serial position).
    One other interesting aspect is that you only need one screw for belt biting on each end.. I've marked this thing a work-in-progress while i solve layer fan for it and thinking on improve with a built-in belt tensioner. Hot-end fan duct is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:222873 that can be fitted and removed without disasembling the carriage.

Center section has holes for m5 nuts,
I finally printed in PLA rather than ABS getting much better result.
You will need to print side sections with support for the side fitting screw holes.

comments.text:
Look what monster I've come up with after a few days of intense CADding .... http://www.thingiverse.com/mbthor/designs

Hello , thanks for your comment !!!
Yesterday i made ​​a thing with a long basis and vertically long walls ( 4 cm / 1.5 inch) . It was a box for an electronic stuff and the result was stunning :) No trace of any wave or layer displacement on any wall. I will publish it when i finish printing and mounting .

comments.author: Carlitros

comments.text:
My design mentioned in a forum!! wow, i didn't expect so much interest :) Thanks for notice me it.
Answering your concerns: Carriage is printed in PLA (not exotic at all, hehehe) and I didnt found any deformation because of hot-end heat. Minimum gap between hot-end and housing is around 3 o 4mm and it looks enough, at least for the 210 ºc that I set for ABS. Printing with PLA I'm around 185 or 190.
The screws to keep hot-end on its position are pretty long to go from side to side of the hot-end (3.5 or 4 cm length), and I only fit them from one of the sides. They fit very tight so hot-end are not moving at all.
comments.author: mbthor

comments.text: Yours shows first one on thingiverse when you search after XCarriage that is this kind I was looking for. It has a sound profile for what I was after (minimal effect on the nozzle for YCarriage rotation around X Axis). Now, depending how your nozzle stands relative to the center of your Y carriage and the center of the Y rods, this might or not be a + i your case :)
